description.narrative: To improve governance frameworks to secure the realization of water related human rights.

WaterLex is a Swiss NGO promoting the implementaton of the UN resolution on water and sanitation as a human right. Financial support from Sida is in the form of a core support of 22 million SEK to be distributed over four years, 2014 - 2017. The general objective of the intervention is: Improved governance frameworks such to secure the realization of water related human rights.
WaterLex' work is organized in two pillars: 1) The Legal Desk, which includes the online legal database, a parliamentarian help desk, the NHRI Water Initiative and capacity development for CSOs. 2) The Operations Desk, which includes capacity building support and development of tools on human rights based approach to water and sanitation and integrated water resources management.

WaterLex är en schweizisk NGO som främjar genomförandet av FN-resolutionen om vatten och sanitet som en mänsklig rättighet. Finansiering från Sida sker i form av kärnstöd på 22 MSEK fördelat på fyra år: 2014 - 2017.
Det övergripande målet med insatsen är: Förbättrade förvaltningsstrukturer för att säkerställa förverkligandet av vatten-relaterade mänskliga rättigheter.
WaterLex verksamhet består i huvudsak av två områden: 1) The Legal Desk, vilken inkluderar en internetbaserad juridisk databas, en parlamentarisk helpdesk, the NHRI Water Initiative samt kapacitetsutveckling för civila samhällets organisationer. 2) The Operations Desk, vilken innefattar kapacitetsbyggande stöd och utveckling av verktyg om mänskliga rättigheter länkade till vatten och sanitet och integrerad vattenresursförvaltning.

sector.narrative: Basic drinking water supply and basic sanitation

policy-marker.narrative: Aid Targeting the Objectives of the Convention on Biological Diversity
Aid Targeting the Objectives of the Convention to Combat Desertification

Reproductive, Maternal, Newborn and Child Health (RMNCH)

description.narrative: During the implementation, WaterLex has reported a number of results under the organisation's areas of work; Below is some examples of results extracted form the annual reports; -Through work with the International Parliamentarian Union, WaterLex has reportedly contributed to raise awareness of human rights in water and sanitation among law makers. This work resulted in requests of assistance in law reform from parliamentarians in Uganda and Kenya (2016) and the creation of a Parliamentarian Network on Water for sharing information about governance and technologies. -Waterlex reported having been instrumental in the process of adapting the African Development Bank's policies to ensure incorporation of human rights to water and sanitation and to adapt the policies to improve the work towards the Sustainable Development Goals, specifically SDG 6. -Work with number small scale water entrepreneurs in compiling with regulations and an human rights based approach in service delivery, resulted in changed behaviours of some suppliers to include wider consultations for marginalised groups, and had altered thinking in social media approaches. -Trainings have been carried out with both water-oriented NGO, national human rights institutions and governments on the human rights to water and sanitation including integrated water resources management (IWRM) aspects. Some IWRM-trainings have been carried out together with Cap-Net UNDP, REDICA, and UNDP Water Governance Facility at SIWI as well as United Nations Institute for Training and Research (UNITAR). WaterLex has routinely followed up the satisfaction level and applicationability of the trainings with a satisfying result. Some results from parters actions, following the training or WaterLex support has been reported. -Mapping of legal frameworks around water and sanitation related laws and policy. In Uganda, WaterLex contributed to legal mapping of water related policies, the mapping in India and Mexico fed in to the special rapporteur on human rights to water and sanitation Léo Heller's visits and dialogues, and mappings in another 5-10 countries has served as a basis for further cooperation. A overarching screening of laws and regulations have been undertaken to inform the date base. -WaterLex has both produced its own handbooks and publications as well as contributed to other’s. -An unexpected result was the involvement of WaterLex in middle east-communications. At one point the interparlamentarian Union invited WaterLex to facilitate a meeting specifically on water for a group in which all communication had stalled. The water subject was perceived tangible and sufficiently "un-politically" to advance communication.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published
